title: Synthetic Recap
body:
WASHINGTON – The rim was a manhole cover and the Washington Wizards had the key. In a dominant 120-99 victory over the New Jersey Nets, the Wizards did not merely win a basketball game; they staged a historic shooting exhibition, orchestrated entirely by their floor general, Rod Strickland.

Strickland was not just the best player on the court; he was a maestro conducting a symphony of efficiency. He carved up the Nets’ defense to the tune of a breathtaking 24 assists, a number that echoes through the annals of the league. Each pass was a dagger, each dish a demoralizing blow to a helpless opponent. Strickland’s vision was omnipresent, finding open men with surgical precision and turning the Capital Centre into his personal highlight reel.

While Strickland orchestrated, his teammates feasted. Calbert Cheaney provided the scoring punch with a team-high 24 points, his cuts and jumpers a direct beneficiary of the playmaking masterclass. The frontcourt duo of Chris Webber (19 points) and Ben Wallace (13 points) controlled the paint, with Wallace adding a monstrous 19 rebounds to anchor the defense.

The Nets, despite a valiant 23-point effort from Kendall Gill and a strong 19-point, 12-rebound double-double from Jayson Williams, were simply buried under an avalanche of ball movement and offensive firepower. They had no answer for the wizardry of Strickland.

On this night, the final score was a mere formality. The real story was the record-book performance of one man. Rod Strickland didn’t just lead his team to a win; he delivered a timeless lesson in the art of the assist, securing his place in NBA lore with a performance for the ages.
